messages.content: Calculus was independently developed in the late 17th century by Isaac Newton and Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz. Newton focused on the concepts of fluxions and fluents, while Leibniz developed a notation system that is still in use today. Both made significant contributions to the field, and their work laid the foundation for modern calculus.

It is not straightforward to determine who was "smarter" between Isaac Newton and Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz, as both were brilliant polymaths who made groundbreaking contributions to multiple fields. Newton is renowned for his work in physics, mathematics, and astronomy, particularly for formulating the laws of motion and universal gravitation. Leibniz is celebrated for his work in mathematics, philosophy, and logic, and for developing the binary number system.

The assessment of intelligence is subjective and context-dependent. Both men were exceptional thinkers whose work has had a profound and lasting impact on science and philosophy.
who is the most famous muslim mathematician

One of the most famous Muslim mathematicians is Al-Khwarizmi, a Persian scholar who lived during the Islamic Golden Age (around the 9th century). He is often referred to as the "father of algebra" due to his significant contributions to the development of algebraic concepts. His work, particularly the book "Al-Kitab al-Mukhtasar fi Hisab al-Jabr wal-Muqabala" (The Compendious Book on Calculation by Completion and Balancing), laid the foundations for the systematic solution of linear and quadratic equations. Additionally, the term "algorithm" is derived from the Latinized form of his name, highlighting his influence on mathematics and computer science.

There is no historical evidence to support the claim that a Muslim scholar had invented calculus before Isaac Newton and Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz. However, scholars from the Islamic Golden Age made significant contributions to mathematics that laid the groundwork for future developments in calculus.

For instance, scholars like Alhazen (Ibn al-Haytham) and Al-Karaji made advancements in areas such as geometry and algebra, and their work with infinitesimals and geometric series can be seen as precursors to calculus concepts. Yet, the formal development of calculus as a distinct mathematical discipline is attributed to Newton and Leibniz in the 17th century.
